results.title: Blush = Hong fen
results.creator_credit: Li Shaohong, Cheng Zhigu, Chen Kunming, Jimmy Tan, Beijing Salon Films and Ocean Films
results.brief_description: Qiuyi and Xiaoe are friends and prostitutes, working in a Shanghai brothel at the end of the 1940’s. It is a time of social upheaval as the Communist Revolution forces them to change their profession and assume ‘normal’ lives. With this normalacy comes trouble, as they both fall in love with the same man. The strain begins to show in their relationship and the two become separated when Quiyi escapes imprisonment by hiding in the home of a former client and Xiaoe becomes trained as a uniformed factory worker. Described as belonging to the renaissance of Asian Cinema, “Blush” is as much about the challenges faced by women during social upheaval as it is about revolutionary change. Cast includes He Saifei and Wang Zhiwen In Mandarin with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Li Shaohong, Cheng Zhigu, Chen Kunming, Jimmy Tan, Beijing Salon Films and Ocean Films

results.title: Blurred
results.creator_credit: Evan Clarry, Chris Brown, Chris Fitchett and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: ‘Its not about the destination but the journey’ is an appropriate cliche to describe this teenage road movie - a group of Year 12 students finish high school and set out by bus, train and car to get to “Schoolies Week” celebrations at the Gold Coast in Queensland. This teenage comedy has a rocking soundtrack that emphasises the excitement as these youth find themselves without boundaries and without parental supervision - they all seek the hedonism of a sex, drugs and rock n’ roll ethos that they think will help them ‘party hard’. But for some along the way old relationships are challenged and a new dynamic emerges as some friends come-of-age on their travels and others simply end up with terrific hangovers. Based on a play by Stephen Davis. Cast includes Tony Brockman, Travis Cotton, Jamie Croft, Jessica Gower, Craig Horner, Mark Priestley, Charlotte Rees, Nathalie Roy, Kristian Schmid, Veronica Sywak, Petra Yared, and Matthew Newton. — Mate (prod. Jan Aird, 1997, 10min.) This witty short film also by filmmaker Evan Clarry is included in the special features. Shot on location in Far North Queensland it is the story of two mates who make a promise to each other that should they die, their remains should be cut up and fed to the local crocodiles. Cast includes Damien Garvey and Andy McDonell.

results.title: Blues Clues: Blue's big treasure hunt
results.creator_credit: Angela Santomero, Todd Kessler, Traci Johnson, Wendy Harris, Nick Jr and Viacom International
results.brief_description: Popular young children’s television program. Encourages children to interact with Steve and follow Steve and his dog Blue on two treasure hunts. Promotes thinking skills such as problem solving and visual perception.

results.title: Blowpipes and Bulldozers
results.creator_credit: Jeni Kendell, Paul Tait and Gala Films
results.brief_description: The story of the Penan tribe is one that is happening regularly all over the planet. It is one which we usually prefer not to know, as it deals with the potential extinction of yet another tribal culture this century. But the twist is that a Swiss man, Bruno Manser, is living and fighting with the Penan and bringing to world attention the fact that once again we of the West are allowing environmental and cultural destruction by our continuing use of rainforest timbers in our daily lives. The story of these people is moving and inspiring and one to stir your heart. Rated: G

results.title: Blowhard
results.creator_credit: Brad Caslor, Christopher Hinton, Derek Mazur, Jerry Krepakevich, Michael Scott, ACCESS and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An animated parable that deals with a familiar subject in an amusing way. We join in the business ventures of J.B. Edwards, an Easterner, who went West to create a fuel company called Consolidated Dragons. The company’s profits were sorely affected when the supply of dragons started to dry up. A solution had to be found - and was. Designed to encourage discussion of energy conservation. (Awards: Yorkton, Rio de Janeiro)

results.title: Blossom time: a romance in the music of Franz Schubert
results.creator_credit: Paul Stein and British International Pictures
results.brief_description: When Schubert (played by Richard Tauber) realizes his love for Vickie is not returned, he helps her overcome the obstacles of the court to find happiness with the man she does love. Throughout the film Tauber sings several of Schubert’s lieder. Music specially adapted and composed by G.H. Clutsam. Cast includes Jane Baxter, Carl Esmond, Athene Seyler, Paul Graetz, Charles Carson, Marguerite Allen.

results.title: Blood sweat and tears. Vol. 1
results.creator_credit: Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by Chris Haywood, this first volume of the “Blood sweat and tears” series contains the following episodes: “Obsession” looks at the seemingly obsessive attention given to sport by both the Australian media and the general public: investigates the questions why are there are sometimes when you can’t get anything on television except sport? and why do most people believe Donald Bradman is the most famous Australian of all time? “Winners and losers” shows the fine line that exists between success and failure in the ruthless world of international sport. “Black diamonds” looks at the issues surrounding Aboriginal achievements in sport. “Kill the bastards” looks at why people immerse themselves in a wider Self - a crowd of supporters, joined at the heart, not the head, bound by the team colours - to whom the one thing that gives life meaning is belonging, even if it means defeat.

results.title: Blood: the last vampire
results.creator_credit: Hiroyuki Kitakubo, Ryuji Mitsumoto, Yukio Nagasaki and Production IG
results.brief_description: It is 1966, and the Vietnam War has just erupted. After a spate of suicides at the military school on the grounds of the U.S controlled Yokota Air Force Base in Japan are attributed to chiropterans, demons who live off human blood, a top secret organisation orders the mysterious and brooding Saya to hunt down and destroy the vile creatures responsible. Armed with a special samurai sword, Saya infiltrates the school in the guise of a new student, and launches a covert investigation, which soon leads her to the source of the problem. However, one of the chiropterans manages to escape, and Saya suddenly has her hands full when the school nurse is captured. It soon becomes a race against time to slay the demons before they take over the Base and kill all the humans within in it. Based on the manga of the same name, this fast-paced film is essentially a section of a much larger story, and is the first fully digital anime ever created. Instead of cels, the film used a computer system that created frames digitally from scanned artwork, using a computer to paint each frame. Director Hiroyuki Katakubo originally started off as an animator, before getting his first gig as a director on the hentai series, Cream Lemon. He has now established himself among the top anime directors, directing films such as ‘Roujin-Z’ (1991) and contributing to an episode of ‘Robot Carnival’ (1987). This video also features a documentary detailing the making of the ‘Blood: the last vampire’.

results.title: Blood sweat and tears. Vol. 2
results.creator_credit: Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by Chris Haywood, this second volume of the four volume series “Blood sweat and tears: Australians and sport”, includes the episodes: “Silvertails & yobbos” which investigates the gulf that exists between the public access areas at sporting venues and the areas reserved for members only - is it really only money that separates the “classes” today? “Beauty and the beast” focuses on the struggle for women against rigid atittudes to be equal in the sporting arena - to have their achievements recognised on the same level as male sporting achievements. “Blood and guts” looks at how a mere game can turn murderous - the increase in violence in sports, such as Australian Rules football, and the extraordinary jump in the number of serious injuries in recent years.
